steps.title: Open Firefox.
steps.content: Open Firefox. Click or double-click the Firefox app icon, which resembles an orange fox on a blue globe. Due to Firefox's built-in tool that allows you to access Flash objects, Firefox is the preferred browser for downloading SWF files.

steps.title: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download.
steps.content: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download. Open the website on which your Flash game or video is hosted.

steps.title: Enable Flash content if necessary.
steps.content: Enable Flash content if necessary. If the game doesn't immediately load, click the prompt or notification to enable Flash, then click Allow or Enable if prompted to confirm your choice. This will reload the page.

steps.title: Wait for the Flash item to load.
steps.content: Wait for the Flash item to load. This is necessary in order to ensure that all of the correct SWF files are loaded in the page.

steps.title: Start the game.
steps.content: Start the game. If you're downloading a Flash game, click the Play (or similar) button to prompt the game to start. This will allow your browser to find the correct SWF files.

steps.title: Right-click a blank part of the page.
steps.content: Right-click a blank part of the page. A drop-down menu will appear. On a Mac, hold down Control while clicking a blank part of the page. Make sure you aren't right-clicking the game window itself.

steps.title: Click View Page Info.
steps.content: Click View Page Info . It's in the drop-down menu. A pop-up window will appear. If you don't see this option, you probably right-clicked an ad or a piece of the game window. Right-click a different part of the page.

steps.title: Click the Media tab.
steps.content: Click the Media tab. This option is at the top of the pop-up window. Doing so displays all of the images, backgrounds, and Flash objects on the page.

steps.title: Look for a SWF file.
steps.content: Look for a SWF file. Scroll down the pop-up window until you find a file with "Object" listed in the "Type" column, then check the file's name to see if it matches the name of the video or game you want to download. SWF files for games often have "API" in the name.

steps.title: Select the SWF file.
steps.content: Select the SWF file. Click the file's name to do so.

steps.title: Click Save As….
steps.content: Click Save As… . It's in the lower-right side of the pop-up window. The file will begin downloading onto your computer. You may need to select a save location or confirm this decision before proceeding.

steps.title: Wait for the SWF file to finish downloading.
steps.content: Wait for the SWF file to finish downloading. Once the file is on your computer, you can proceed.

steps.title: Try opening the SWF file
steps.content: Try opening the SWF file . You can use a free program to open and play the SWF file. If the file plays correctly, you've successfully downloaded the right SWF file. If your downloaded SWF file doesn't open or isn't the correct file, you'll need to go back and try a different "Object" file. If there are no more "Object" files, your SWF file can't be downloaded.

steps.title: Open Google Chrome.
steps.content: Open Google Chrome. Click or double-click the Chrome app icon, which resembles a red, yellow, green, and blue sphere.

steps.title: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download.
steps.content: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download. Open the website on which your Flash game or video is hosted.

steps.title: Enable Flash content if necessary.
steps.content: Enable Flash content if necessary. If the game doesn't immediately load, click the Click to enable Adobe Flash Player section, then click Allow when prompted. Some sites will have a different button (e.g., Enable/Install Flash ) instead of the Click to enable Adobe Flash Player option.

steps.title: Wait for the Flash item to load.
steps.content: Wait for the Flash item to load. This is necessary in order to ensure that all of the correct SWF files are loaded in the page.

steps.title: Start the game.
steps.content: Start the game. If you're downloading a Flash game, click the Play (or similar) button to prompt the game to start. This will allow your browser to find the correct SWF files.

steps.title: Click ⋮.
steps.content: Click ⋮ . This is in the top-right corner of Chrome. Clicking it prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select More tools.
steps.content: Select More tools . It's in the drop-down menu. A pop-out menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Developer tools.
steps.content: Click Developer tools . This is in the pop-out menu. Doing so opens the Developer pane on the right side of the page.

steps.title: Click the Elements tab.
steps.content: Click the Elements tab. It's at the top of the pane.

steps.title: Bring up the "Find" search bar.
steps.content: Bring up the "Find" search bar. Press either Ctrl + F (Windows) or ⌘ Command + F (Mac) to do so.

steps.title: Type in swf.
steps.content: Type in swf . Doing so will highlight each instance of "SWF" appearing in the source code.

steps.title: Find the address for the SWF file.
steps.content: Find the address for the SWF file. Scroll through the source code to review the highlighted "SWF" options. You're looking for an address that matches the site and/or game or video title (e.g., "flashgames/games/gamename.swf") rather than a string of code.

steps.title: Copy the SWF file's address.
steps.content: Copy the SWF file's address. Once you find the address, click once the address to select its block of code, then press Ctrl + C (Windows) or ⌘ Command + C (Mac). Since Chrome doesn't let you select an individual line of text, you may have to copy an entire block of code.

steps.title: Paste the address into Chrome's address bar.
steps.content: Paste the address into Chrome's address bar. Click the address bar, then press Ctrl + V or ⌘ Command + V to paste the address into it. Since you copied an entire block of code, you'll need to remove the code before and after the address before proceeding.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . Doing so will prompt the SWF file to download onto your computer.

steps.title: Wait for the SWF file to download.
steps.content: Wait for the SWF file to download. Once it's on your computer, you can proceed. If prompted, click Keep on the prompt warning you that SWF files can harm your computer. You may also have to select a save location.

steps.title: Try opening the SWF file
steps.content: Try opening the SWF file . You can use a free program to open and play the SWF file. If the file plays correctly, you've successfully downloaded the right SWF file. If your downloaded SWF file doesn't open or isn't the correct file, you'll need to go back and try a different SWF address in the Developer Tools tab.

steps.title: Open Microsoft Edge.
steps.content: Open Microsoft Edge. Click or double-click the Edge app icon, which resembles either a dark-blue "e" or a white "e" on a dark-blue background.

steps.title: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download.
steps.content: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download. Open the website on which your Flash game or video is hosted.

steps.title: Enable Flash content if necessary.
steps.content: Enable Flash content if necessary. If the game doesn't immediately load, click the puzzle piece-shaped Flash icon in the address bar, then click the Enable or Allow prompt to enable Flash and reload the page.

steps.title: Wait for the Flash item to load.
steps.content: Wait for the Flash item to load. This is necessary in order to ensure that all of the correct SWF files are loaded in the page.

steps.title: Start the game.
steps.content: Start the game. If you're downloading a Flash game, click the Play (or similar) button to prompt the game to start. This will allow your browser to find the correct SWF files.

steps.title: Click ⋯.
steps.content: Click ⋯ . It's in the upper-right side of the window. A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Developer Tools.
steps.content: Click Developer Tools . This is in the drop-down menu. Doing so opens the Developer Tools pane on the right side of the page. You might want to reduce the right side of the pane by clicking and dragging right the scroll bar in the middle of the pane. This will make searching the Elements tab easier.

steps.title: Click the Elements tab.
steps.content: Click the Elements tab. It's at the top of the Developer Tools pane.

steps.title: Bring up the "Find" search bar.
steps.content: Bring up the "Find" search bar. Press Ctrl + F to do so. Your mouse cursor will automatically be placed in the search bar.

steps.title: Type in swf.
steps.content: Type in swf . Doing so will highlight any instances of SWF files in the Elements tab.

steps.title: Find the address for the SWF file.
steps.content: Find the address for the SWF file. Click the left- or right-facing arrow in the right-most corner of the search bar to skip from one instance of a SWF file to the next, making sure to read the string of text before each SWF instance. You're looking for an address that matches the site and/or game or video title (e.g., "flashgames/games/gamename.swf") rather than a string of code. Since the Elements tab isn't very wide, you might have to click and drag left or right the scroll bar at the bottom of it to see your SWF results.

steps.title: Copy the SWF file's address.
steps.content: Copy the SWF file's address. Once you find the address, click and drag your mouse cursor across it, then press Ctrl + C . You may not be able to copy the address without copying the whole block of code.

steps.title: Paste the SWF file's address into the address bar.
steps.content: Paste the SWF file's address into the address bar. Click the address bar at the top of the Edge window, then press Ctrl + V . You should see the address appear here. If you were unable to copy the address by itself, remove the sections of code before and after the address before proceeding. This is easiest to do in a text editor such as Notepad (Windows) or TextEdit (Mac).

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . Doing so will prompt the SWF file to begin downloading.

steps.title: Wait for the SWF file to download.
steps.content: Wait for the SWF file to download. Once the SWF file finishes downloading, you can proceed. If asked if you want to save the SWF file, confirm the decision. You may also have to select a save location.

steps.title: Try opening the SWF file
steps.content: Try opening the SWF file . You can use a free program to open and play the SWF file. If the file plays correctly, you've successfully downloaded the right SWF file. If your downloaded SWF file doesn't open or isn't the correct file, you'll need to go back and try a different SWF address in the Developer Tools tab.

steps.title: Open Safari.
steps.content: Open Safari. Click the Safari app icon, which resembles a blue compass, in your Mac's Dock.

steps.title: Enable the Develop menu item if necessary.
steps.content: Enable the Develop menu item if necessary. If you don't have the Develop menu item at the top of your Mac's screen while Safari is open, do the following: Click Safari in the top-left corner of the screen. Click Preferences... in the drop-down menu. Click the Advanced tab. Check the "Show Develop menu in menu bar" box. Close the Preferences window.

steps.title: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download.
steps.content: Go to the Flash video or game you want to download. Open the website on which your Flash game or video is hosted.

steps.title: Enable Flash content if necessary.
steps.content: Enable Flash content if necessary. If prompted, click the Enable or Allow button to allow Flash on the webpage.

steps.title: Wait for the Flash item to load.
steps.content: Wait for the Flash item to load. This is necessary in order to ensure that all of the correct SWF files are loaded in the page.

steps.title: Start the game.
steps.content: Start the game. If you're downloading a Flash game, click the Play (or similar) button to prompt the game to start. This will allow your browser to find the correct SWF files.

steps.title: Click Develop.
steps.content: Click Develop . This option is in the menu bar at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Show Page Source.
steps.content: Click Show Page Source . It's in the Develop drop-down menu. You should see the page's source code appear.

steps.title: Bring up the "Find" search bar.
steps.content: Bring up the "Find" search bar. Press ⌘ Command + F to do so.

steps.title: Type in swf.
steps.content: Type in swf . This will cause Safari to highlight any "SWF" sections in the source code.

steps.title: Find the address for the SWF file.
steps.content: Find the address for the SWF file. Scroll through the Page Source pane to review any highlighted "SWF" sections. You're looking for an address that matches the site and/or game or video title (e.g., "flashgames/games/gamename.swf") rather than a string of code.

steps.title: Copy the SWF file's address.
steps.content: Copy the SWF file's address. Click and drag your mouse cursor across the address, then press ⌘ Command + C to copy it. You may not be able to copy the address without copying the whole block of code.

steps.title: Paste the address into Safari's address bar.
steps.content: Paste the address into Safari's address bar. Click the address bar at the top of the Safari window, then press ⌘ Command + V . You should see the address appear here. If you were unable to copy the address by itself, remove the sections of code before and after the address before proceeding. This is easiest to do in a text editor such as TextEdit.

steps.title: Press ⏎ Return.
steps.content: Press ⏎ Return . Doing so will prompt the SWF file to begin downloading.

steps.title: Wait for the SWF file to download.
steps.content: Wait for the SWF file to download. Once the SWF file is on your computer, you can proceed. If asked if you want to save the SWF file, confirm the decision. You may also have to select a save location.

steps.title: Try opening the SWF file
steps.content: Try opening the SWF file . You can use a free program to open and play the SWF file. If the file plays correctly, you've successfully downloaded the right SWF file. If your downloaded SWF file doesn't open or isn't the correct file, you'll need to go back and try a different SWF address.
